description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Kärnstöd till International Center for Not-for-Profit Law
Det är en global trend att utrymmet för det civila samhället att verka fritt begränsas och minskar. Sida har sedan 2012 stött det icke-vinstdrivande företaget International Center for Not-for-Profit Law (ICNL) och dess arbete inom ramen för Civic Space Initiative (CSI), för att vända denna trend. Nu aktuell insats kommer att utformas som ett kärnstöd till ICNL:s samlade verksamhet som innefattar ICNL:s roll i genomförandet av CSI. Insatsens fokus ligger på den rättsliga miljön och civila samhällets delaktighet, och sker genom insatser på global, regional och nationell nivå. Sidas stöd avser perioden 2016-2021 och omfattar totalt 81 900 000 SEK. Omkring 25 procent av budgeten kommer att vidareförmedlas till ca 35 av ICNL:s lokala samarbetsorganisationer, de flesta med en tydlig inriktning på rättslig reform.
ICNL etablerades 1992 och har sedan dess arbetat med reform i över 100 länder. Organisationen strävar efter att uppnå ett juridiskt klimat som möjliggör för människor att tillsammans förbättra sina samhällen. ICNL stödjer lokala initiativ genom att bidra med internationell expertis gällande analys och reformstrategier i relation till lagstiftning och reglering som berör civilsamhället. ICNL har omkring 75 anställda, varav 25 i Washington. Övriga är lokaliserade i Budapest, Sofia, Almaty, Amman, Asghabat, Bishek, Dushanbe, Kabul och Moskva. Verksamheten bedrivs dock i många fler länder än där ICNL har kontor.
Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Core support to International Center for Not-for-Profit Law

The objectives and expected results of the Core Activities are: To support the implementation of ICNL' Strategic Plan 2017-2022. ICNL'S mission is to promote the freedoms of association, expression, and assembly, thereby providing an enabling environment for civil society, civic participation, philanthropy, and development cooperation ('civic space"). ICNL advances this mission through the following strategic objectives:
- Enhancing international norms and multilateral engagement to safeguard the freedoms of association, expression, and assembly.
- Empowering local partners to advocate for national-level laws and policies that protect the freedoms of association, expression, and assembly.
- lncreasing the capacity of individuals and organizations to navigate legal frameworks affecting civil society, philanthropy, civic participation, and development cooperation.
- Advancing research and information sharing on civic space. Raising public awareness to protect civic space.

tag.narrative: 16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

description.narrative:
Due to the Covid-19-pandemic in 2020 ICNL sought to respond to the disruption with innovation that is in line with and integrated into ICNL's Strategic Plan. For instance, ICNL created a digital tool, "Covid-19 Civic Freedom Tracker", on their web page (www.icnl.org) with the purpose to monitor government repsonses to the pandemic that affect civic freedom and human rights. In addition to this they organised virtual meetings with partners in six regions to share experiences of covid-inspired measures and develop strategies to address challenges. Specific grants, technical assistance and other support to partners engaged in addressing Covid-inspired constraints on fundamental freedoms were provisioned.
The five strategic objectives and results highlights
Objective 1 Enhancing international norms and multilateral engagement to safeguard the freedoms of association, expression and assembly:
ICNL helped influence the content of 70 policy actions in support of civic space through the UN system, multi-stakeholder organisations and global and regional bodies.
Objective 2 Empowering local partners to advocate for national-level laws and policies that protect the freedoms of association, expression and assembly:
ICNL advanced legal reform in over 60 countries by providing technical assistance and supporting in-country partners' reform efforts. ICNL helped build the capacity of over 2700 organisations to advance legal reform and 460 CSO's took concrete steps to advance legal reform in their countries.
Objective 3 Increasing the capacity of individuals and organisations to navigate legal frameworks affecting civil society, civic participation, philanthropy and development cooperation:
ICNL supported partners and the broader CSO community to adopt to the changing regulatory landscape in 43 countries. ICNL helped more than 5200 CSO's and other stakeholders to advance their capacity to navigate CSO legal environments.
Objective 4 Advancing research and information sharing on civic space:
ICNL provided up-to-date information on civic space in countries around the world through the Civic Freedom Monitor, which currently includes eight multilateral organisation reports and 55 country reports. In 2020 the reports were accessed by over 25 000 people.
Objective 5 Raising public awareness to protect civic space:
ICNL contributed to a series of international and national meetings and initiatives aimed at broadening the awareness of civic space issues among a variety of audiences. For instance a Tech Camp with topics such as artificial intelligence and machine learning for 26 civic space defenders was organised in collaboration with Stanford University's Global Digital Policy Incubator. In follow-up to the camp an Innovation Fund was created to provide support to participants in addressing human rights impacts of artificial intelligence.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
